caseName: United States v. Farina
caseNameFull: UNITED STATES v. FARINA Et Al.
court: Court of Appeals for the Second Circuit

opinions.snippet:
FRANK, Circuit Judge
(dissenting).
What influences juries, courts seldom know. Indeed, most courts (including the federal courts) not only do not diligently seek such knowledge but have a general policy of deliberate unwillingness to learn —and usually seal up the only possible sources from which they could learn — what occurred in the jury-room. As we recently said

The possessor of land is subject to liability for bodily harm to young children trespassing thereon caused by a structural or other artificial condition which he maintains upon the land if, (a) the place where the condition is maintained is one upon which the possessor knows, or should know, that such children are likely to trespass; (b) the condition is one of which the possessor knows, or should know, and which he realizes, or should realize, involves an unreasonable risk of death or serious bodily harm to such children; (c) the children, because of their youth, do not discover the condition or realize the risk involved in intermeddling in it or in coming within the area made dangerous by it; and (d) the utility to the possessor of maintaining the condition is slight as compared to the risk to young children involved therein.

opinions.snippet: An action was brought in the Circuit Court of Lauderdale County by the heirs of Billie Mitchell Barnhill, demanding damages for his death by drowning in an old vat which had been built in connection with a former bleaching plant, long since out of business, and its buildings torn down. The location was in the outskirts of Meridian, in a field of approximately six acres. On a different part of this field, children were accustomed frequently to play baseball. posture: Appeal from Circuit Court, Hinds County, L. Breland Hilburn, J. Page 330

attorney: Noble J. Russell, Decatur, and Deramus, Fitts, Johnston Mullins, Birmingham, for appellants. Conditional statements of the type alleged in the complaint are not actionable. McKee v. Ingalls, 4 Scam. 30, 5 Ill. 30 . Testimony as to past successes in similar undertakings is not competent evidence in a determination of losses sustained by a plaintiff who complains of the frustration of an executory undertaking. Union Ref. Co. v. Barton, 77 Ala. 148 ; Deslandes v. Scales, 187 Ala. 25 , 65 So. 393 . Unless there is a factual foundation in the record for expert testimony, such testimony is without probative value, and its admission for the purpose of proving substantial damages constitutes reversible error. Brown v. Mobile Elec. Co., 207 Ala. 61 , 91 So. 802 ; Stewart v. Sloss-S. S. I. Co., 170 Ala. 544 , 54 So. 48 ; Knowlton v. Central of Ga. R. Co., 192 Ala. 456 , 68 So. 281 ; Birmingham R. E. Co. v. Baylor, 101 Ala. 488 , 489 , 13 So. 793 ; Raub v. Carpenter, 187 U.S. 159 , 23 S.Ct. 72 , 74 L.Ed. 119 ; 2 Wigmore Evid. (3d. Ed.) § 672. In order to recover of a corporation for a libel published by an agent of the corporation it must be shown either that the corporation specifically authorized the publication of the very libel, or that the libel was published by the agent while acting within the scope of his general authority in the furtherance of the corporation's business, or that the corporation subsequently ratified the publication of the libel by the agent. Choctaw C. M. Co. v. Lillich, 204 Ala. 533 , 86 So. 383 , 11 A.L.R. 1014; 13 Am.Jur. Corporatives, § 1126; Weir v. Brotherhood, 221 Ala. 494 , 129 So. 267 ; Louisville N. R. Co. v. Germany, 27 Ala. App. 595 , 176 So. 837 ; 2 Fletcher CYC. Corp. § 756. A verdict contrary to the great weight of the evidence should be set aside on motion. Birmingham Nat. Bank v. Bradley, 116 Ala. 142 , 23 So. 53 ; Id., Ala., 30 So. 546 ; Carraway v. Graham, 218 Ala. 453 , 118 So. 807 ; Yarbrough v. Mallory, 225 Ala. 579 , 144 So. 447 . Hare, Wynn Newell, Birmingham, and Ling Bains, Bessemer, for appellee. If defendant makes the charge to depend upon a fact which he has stated conditionally, but it is known to be true, it is equivalent to a direct charge and actionable. 36 C.J. 1155; 53 C.J.S., Libel and Slander, § 9, p. 47. Where the tort itself is of such nature as to preclude the ascertainment of the amount of damages with certainty, while the damages may not be determined by mere speculation or guess, it will be enough if the evidence shows the extent of the damages as a matter of just and reasonable inference although the result may be approximate. Story Parchment Co. v. Paterson P. P. Co., 282 U.S. 555 , 51 S.Ct. 248 , 75 L.Ed. 544 ; McCormack, Damages (1935 Ed.) 97, 33 Am.Jur. 188; Kimball v. Boston Transcript Co., 199 Mass. 248 , 85 N.E. 103 , 19 L.R.A., N.S., 862; 25 C.J.S., Damages, § 28, p. 493; Harris v. National Union, 116 Cal.App.2d 759 , 254 P.2d 673 ; Ditus v. Beahm, 123 Colo. 550 , 232 P.2d 184 ; H. D. Watts Co. v. American B. M. Co., 267 Mass. 541 , 166 N.E. 713 ; 3 Restatement, Torts, 316; 4 Restatement, Torts, 574. There is no merit in the contention that Forsyth could not give opinion testimony without stating the facts on which he based his opinion. He did state such facts. This rule has no application to questions calling for opinion of expert who has personal knowledge of the subject of inquiry. Birmingham Amusement Co. v. Norris, 216 Ala. 138 , 112 So. 633 , 637 , 53 A.L.R. 840. The libel in this case was committed by the agent of the corporation within the line and scope of his general authority. Berry v. City of N.Y. Ins. Co., 210 Ala. 369 , 98 So. 290 ; 13 A.L.R. 1143; Wells v. Payne, 141 Ky. 578 , 133 S.W. 575 . The question of ratification vel non by the corporation was one for the jury. 13 Am.Jur. 934; Wells v. Payne, supra; Interstate Transit Lines v. Crane, 10 Cir., 100 F.2d 857 ; Washington Gaslight Co. v. Lansden, 172 U.S. 534 , 19 S.Ct. 296 , 43 L.Ed. 543 . Page 309

caseNameFull: O'Toole v. Duluth, South Shore & Atlantic Railway Company

opinions.snippet:
Timlin, J.
(dissenting). By ch. 332, Laws of 1909, it was provided that in actions for death or personal injuries caused by the negligent omission of a railroad company to comply with the requirements of sec. 1809, the fact that the person injured or killed was guilty of a slight want of ordinary care contributing to the injury or death should not bar a recovery. “The burden of proof that the person so injured <page-number citatio

caseName: Planned Parenthood of Central Missouri v. Danforth
caseNameFull: PLANNED PARENTHOOD OF CENTRAL MISSOURI Et Al. v. DANFORTH, ATTORNEY GENERAL OF MISSOURI, Et Al.
court: Supreme Court of the United States
judge: Blackmun, Powell, Rehnquist, Stevens, Stewart, White

opinions.snippet:
Mr. Justice Blackmun
delivered the opinion of the Court.
This case is a logical and anticipated corollary to Roe v. Wade, 410 U. S. 113 (1973), and Doe v. Bolton, 410 U. S. 179 (1973), for it raises issues secondary to those that were then before the Court. Indeed, some of the questions now presented were forecast and reserved in Roe and Doe. 410 U. S., at 16
